fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be an effective equivalence relation in a regular category. Then a,b\colon R\rightrightarrows A admit a coequalizer d. Moreover, (a,b) is a kernel pair of d.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition, (a,b) is a kernel pair of some morphism. Then the result follows immediately from .

fr:title.text: Every kernel pair has a coequalizer

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every kernel pair has a coequalizer

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a regular category, every kernel pair has a coequalizer. Moreover, the given kernel pair is also a kernel pair of the coequalizer.

Let a,b\colon R\rightrightarrows A be the kernel pair of a morphism f\colon A\to B. Consider the cover-mono factorization of f: f = f_{m}f_{c}. By , it suffices to show that (a,b) is a kernel pair of f_{c}, i.e., the following diagram is a pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = R, ne = A, sw = A, se = {\mathsf {Img}(f)}, north = b, west = a, south = {f_{c}}, south/style = {cover}, east = {f_{c}}, east/style = {cover}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: First, the diagram commutes since fa = f_{m}f_{c}a = f_{m}f_{c}b = fb by definition, and f_{m} is monic. Let h,k\colon C\rightrightarrows A be a pair of morphisms such that f_{c}h = f_{c}k. Then f_{m}f_{c}h = fh = fk = f_{m}f_{c}k. Thus, the unique factor is given by the following pullback.

fr:title.text: Every monomorphism is regular in a pretopos

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every monomorphism is regular in a pretopos

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a pretopos, every monomorphism is regular.
Let f\colon A\rightarrowtail B be a monomorphism in a pretopos. By , there is a pullback square

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = B, se = C, north = f, north/style = {>->}, west = f, west/style = {>->}, south = h, south/style = {>->}, east = k, east/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: But, this pullback square is an equalizer of h and k.

Let A_{1} and A_{2} be subobjects of A in a coherent category such that A_{1} \cap A_{2} \cong 0. Then A_{1} \cup A_{2} \cong A_{1} + A_{2}. Note that every coherent category has a (strict) initial object by .
By the following diagram is a pushout.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = 0, ne = {A_{2}}, sw = {A_{1}}, se = {A_{1} \cup A_{2}}, north/style = {>->,exists}, west/style = {>->,exists}, south/style = {>->}, east/style = {>->}, }

fr:title.text: Categories with a subobject classifier are cartesian

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Categories with a subobject classifier are cartesian

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathcal {C} is a category with pullbacks equipped with a subobject classifier then \mathcal {C} is cartesian.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By , \mathcal {C} has a terminal object. Thus, it follows that \mathcal {C} has all finite limits.

fr:title.text: Domain of the generic subobject is terminal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain of the generic subobject is terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \top \colon \Omega '\to \Omega be the generic subobject of a category \mathcal {C} with pullbacks, then \Omega ' is terminal.
Let A be any object in a topos and let \{\}\colon A \to \Omega ^{A} be the name of the diagonal relation \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A. \{\} is a monomorphism.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By , every monomorphism is regular. Thus, any epic monomorphism is automatically an isomorphism.

fr:title.text: Monomorphisms are equalizers in a topos

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monomorphisms are equalizers in a topos

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a topos, every monomorphism is an equalizer.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is an immediate consequence of .
